persons.name: JohnLeslie
persons.description: Scottish mathematician and physicist, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, best known for his research into heat.

persons.name: JohnLeslie
persons.description: Scottish mathematician and physicist, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, best known for his research into heat.

persons.name: Marc-AugustePictet
persons.description: Genevan natural philosopher and journal editor. Corresponded with Davy. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: PierrePrevost
persons.description: A Genevan philosopher and physicist. In 1791 he explained Pictet's experiment by arguing that all bodies radiate heat, no matter how hot or cold they are.

persons.name: Frederick WilliamHerschel
persons.description: Hanoverian astronomer and composer who while living in Bath discovered the planet later named Uranus. Moving to Slough he built the world's largest telescope to date which Davy visited when he was courting Jane Apreece. FRSL.

persons.name: Henry CharlesEnglefield
persons.description: Seventh baronet from 1780 and a prominent Roman Catholic antiquarian and geologist. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

persons.name: Lucretius
persons.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

persons.name: AdairCrawford
persons.description: A British chemist, physician, and fellow of the Royal Society. He was a pioneer in the development of calorimetric methods for measuring the specific heat capacity of substances and the heat of chemical reactions.

persons.name: GeorgeFordyce
persons.description: Scottish physician, lecturer on medicine and chemist who worked in London. FRSL.

persons.name: Daniel CarlssonSolander
persons.description: Swedish-born naturalist who worked at the British Museum cataloguing their natural history collections according to the Linnean system. Close to Banks, he accompanied him on various vayages including the Endeavour expedition to the Pacific. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephBanks
persons.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesBlagden
persons.description: Physician who kept a revealing diary for most of his life. A friend of Joseph Banks serving as a Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1784-1797; Knighted 1792. FRSL

persons.name: Peter SimonPallas
persons.description: Prussian explorer, geologist and botanist, who wrote 'Second Voyage de Pallas, ou Voyages entrpris dans les gouvernmens meridionaux de l'empire de Russie, pendant les annees 1793 et 94'

places.name: United States
places.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

places.name: Siberia
places.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

persons.name: BenjaminThompson
persons.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

places.name: Pacific Ocean
places.description: The largest and deepest of Earth's five oceans.

persons.name: JohnLeslie
persons.description: Scottish mathematician and physicist, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, best known for his research into heat.

persons.name: DenisPapin
persons.description: French-born assistant in the Royal Society of London. Developed an early form of the steam engine. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

persons.name: WilliamIrvine
persons.description: FRSE 18th-century British doctor and chemist who served as assistant to Joseph Black in many of his important experiments.

persons.name: AdairCrawford
persons.description: A British chemist, physician, and fellow of the Royal Society. He was a pioneer in the development of calorimetric methods for measuring the specific heat capacity of substances and the heat of chemical reactions.

persons.name: GeorgeFordyce
persons.description: Scottish physician, lecturer on medicine and chemist who worked in London. FRSL.

persons.name: CharlesBlagden
persons.description: Physician who kept a revealing diary for most of his life. A friend of Joseph Banks serving as a Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1784-1797; Knighted 1792. FRSL

persons.name: AdairCrawford
persons.description: A British chemist, physician, and fellow of the Royal Society. He was a pioneer in the development of calorimetric methods for measuring the specific heat capacity of substances and the heat of chemical reactions.

works.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London

places.name: Africa
places.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Frederick WilliamHerschel
persons.description: Hanoverian astronomer and composer who while living in Bath discovered the planet later named Uranus. Moving to Slough he built the world's largest telescope to date which Davy visited when he was courting Jane Apreece. FRSL.
